description: Various points suggest a post-Indo-European borrowing from an unknown source: * The phoneme *b, which is rare and of somewhat doubtful status. * The consistent occurrence of *a. * The alternation between *k and geminate *kk across the descendants. According to Oxford's Introduction to proto-Indo-European, the initial *b- may have been due to the informal ("popular") nature of the term. Kroonen and De Vaan reconstruct no Proto-Indo-European form at all.

english_translation: to dig, burrow; to pierce, stab
description: The root is considered to be a member of the so-called ''mol≈ç-present'' class‚Äïroots which conjugate with the early h‚ÇÇe-conjugation in present and exhibit R(e/o)-ablaut.
The existence of this root is highly tentative, as most of the descendants have disputed etymologies and are only loosely semantically related.
Apparently originally the same root as the synonymous *b ∞ewg-.

english_translation: to shine, glow light; to appear, be visible

description: This root could presumably have an *a, but the short vowel of *b ∞aga- can easily be explained by Lubotsky's Law, from the loss of the laryngeal in front of a voiced stop plus another consonant; this condition would have existed, for instance, in athematic verb forms, such as *b ∞egs-.

english_translation: to bake, to roast, to fry
to sound; to speak, roar, bark
description: Pokorny lists *bhel- "henbane" separately but allows the possibility that it is the same as *bhel- "shiny, white."
Palatovelar assumed based on purported connection to the Balto-Slavic words that are more accurately from *b ∞el«µ ∞- (see note 2).
The verbal senses "to grow, thicken" are found in Indo-Iranian, but their inherited status is disputed.

english_translation: to rise up, ascend; to be elevated, up high
to safeguard, to protect; to preserve

description: The Sanskrit forms with long ƒÅ can be explained as an irregular development of earlier *ay < *ey/*oy.

english_translation: to shake, tremble; to fear, be afraid

description: Potentially an attributive verb "to be harmonious, friendly." Derivations in daughter languages can also be explained as derivations of a verb.
The Latin stem flƒÅ- may be from the zero-grade *b ∞lÃ•h‚ÇÅ-, resulting in a root *flƒÅ- from which the other Latin forms were derived analogically.

english_translation: to blend, to mix up; to make cloudy, opaque; blond, red-haired, ruddy (alternative/contested)

description: Possible laryngeal extension of *b ∞lew-, whence œÜŒªŒ≠œâ (to overflow, flood), itself possibly suffixed in *-√©wti/*-ew- from *b ∞el- (to blow (up), swell).

english_translation: to smell, to have a strong odour
description: If gmh br√¶hen from gem-pro *brƒìkijanƒÖ belongs here, then the laryngeal can be reconstructed as *b ∞reh‚ÇÅg-
Reconstructed with a labiovelar to include la:frequƒìns, but due to this unusual root structure, possibly a qfa-sub borrowing.

english_translation: to make use of; have enjoyment of

description: Some sources reconstruct full-grade forms *b ∞ewh‚ÇÇ- or *b ∞weh‚ÇÇ-, on the basis of Italic and Celtic preterite and subjunctive stem. The generalisation of the zero grade in most forms has been linked to the occurrence of labial occlusive + labial semivowel in the full grade *b ∞weh‚ÇÇ-. According to Jasanoff, this root has no full grade, and the laryngeal cannot be precisely determined.

english_translation: to build (up), to arrange, to put together
to split, to separate; to tear, to crack, to shatter
to tug, to stretch; to pluck
description: Rix and Derksen reconstruct a laryngeal in the coda because of the Balto-Slavic acute. LIV points that the Albanian data may have originated from *swer- ("to ache"). According to some (e.g. Trubachyov), the root is an extension of *der- ("to tear").

english_translation: to pull, to draw; to lead (i.e. to pull behind oneself)
to point out, to show; to speak solemnly

description: Probably related to *dw√≥h‚ÇÅ "two", with sense connection "two" > "ambivalence, second thoughts" > "fear".

english_translation: to be bright, to shine; sky, heaven
to set in motion, to flow
to bind fast, to be firm, to support, strong, robust
description: Possibly an extension of *d ∞er-, to hold, hold fast, support.

english_translation: to hit (as opposed to missing), to produce, to be strong, have force

description: Seemingly related to *d ∞wes- 'breath; dust; dusky color'.

english_translation: to knead, to form, to shape
to stick into, pierce; to dig; to plant; to set up, fasten

description: Reanalysed root of *d ∞g ∑ ∞√©yti, from *d ∞eg ∑ ∞- "to burn" + *-√©y-present suffix

english_translation: to run, to drag, to pull
description: some of the forms listed here as descendants have been argued to be either from unrelated roots, or to be related by means of being post-IE loanwords

english_translation: to breathe (in or out), breath, spirit, soul, dust, dusty, murky color
description: Seemingly related to *d ∞ewh‚ÇÇ- (to emit) smoke, vapor, mist, haze, with which there may be confusion in some descendants.
Likely onomatopoeic. Compare *gerh‚ÇÇ- ~ *«µerh‚ÇÇ-, with which there is some confusion.

english_translation: to bite, to chomp, to crunch
description: From Proto-Indo-European *«µ-n√©-b ∞-ti ~ *«µ-mÃ•-b ∞-√©nti, nasal inflix of a poorly contested root, *«µeb ∞-, possibly found in Proto-Celtic *gobbos ("muzzle, snout"), Gaulish *gauta ("cheek").

english_translation: to produce, to beget, to give birth

description: Reconstruction:Proto-Indo-European root meaning 'to defecate' or related to bodily functions.

LIV and Mayrhofer reconstruct two separate roots *«µ ∞ers- and *g‚ÅΩ ∑‚Åæ ∞ers- for the material, but according to Lubotsky this isn't necessary as forms like ‡§ò‡•É‡§∑‡•Å can be explained by Weise's law (depalatalization before *r).

english_translation: hand, to take, give in exchange

description: The existence of this root is uncertain.

english_translation: to shine, glow; to be shining, glowing
description: Thought to be a reanalyzed root from *«µ ∞el-/t1=to shine/*-√©h‚ÇÅti/pos2=fientive verb suffix, whence also *«µ ∞ley-/t=to shine. Often mistakenly undifferentiated from *«µ ∞elh‚ÇÉ-/t=to flourish; green, yellow.

english_translation: to vex, torment; to be angry, upset
description: Depalatalization of *«µ before *r in Indo-Iranian due to Weise's Law.

Indo-Iranian and Balto-Slavic show the presence of an *-i- at several different locations in the root. The LIV suggests the reanalysis of a *ye- present as part of the root itself with later metathesis of *g‚ÅΩ ∑‚ÅæHi- to *g‚ÅΩ ∑‚ÅæiH- and then normalization to *g‚ÅΩ ∑‚ÅæeyH- ~ *g‚ÅΩ ∑‚ÅæiH-.

Formally unable to be related to *klÃ•H-; however, the superficial phonetic and semantic resemblance of the two roots, as well as the existence of words meaning "bald" (a non-basic vocabulary term) in various descendants of both roots via the same suffixing pattern of -w√≥-s, is striking.
Likely onomatopoeic. Compare *«µeh‚ÇÇr- (with which there is some confusion) *kurke (crane), Akkadian íÜ≥íÑÑíÑ∑ (kurku), Sumerian íÜ≥íÑÑíÑ∑ (kurki).

english_translation: to call, name; to invoke, call on; to cry, cry out
to ball up, clump together; swelling, lump
to smear, putty; to stick, glue
to find, to hold, to seize, to take
to join, to unite, to suit

description: Derived from a repeating root *g ∞e-g ∞u-«µ ∞-, of onomatopoeic origin.

The surface ablaut a ~ ƒì is somewhat unusual, but Italo-Celtic *a can result from "syllabic" *HÃ•, thus *h‚ÇÅ ~ *eh‚ÇÅ appears to be the best match. The instances of full-grade ƒì may be analogical, however, so the laryngeal cannot be reconstructed with certainty.

english_translation: to call, to chant, to shout

description: Traditionally considered separate extensions (or suffixed forms) of a root *g ∞el-, namely *g ∞el-t- in Germanic and *g ∞el-d‚ÅΩ ∞‚Åæ- in Slavic, not taking into account the Celtic. Some authors maintain that *-t- (> Germanic *-√æ-) is necessary to explain such Nordic forms as gjalla.

english_translation: to enclose, to encircle; enclosure, fence, belt

description: Possible reanalyzed root of *g ∞leh‚ÇÇ-*-d ∞h‚ÇÅeti, metathesized from *«µ ∞elh‚ÇÇ- 'to shine', itself apparently related to *«µ ∞elh‚ÇÉ- 'to flourish; green, yellow'.

english_translation: to seize, grab; to dig, rake
description: Rix reconstructs *g ∞rebh‚ÇÇ- 'seize' and tentatively *g ∞reb ∞- 'dig'. Pokorny reconstructs *g ∞reb ∞-, *g ∞erb ∞- for both meanings. Derksen derives *grabiti from *g ∞reb- rather than *g ∞reb ∞- due to Winter's law.

english_translation: to roar, rumble; to thunder; to be angry
description: An old sound symbolic root according to Kroonen.
Given the variety of conflicting reconstructions and fairly wide semantic range, existence of this root is uncertain.

english_translation: to smear, to paint, to streak
description: Extended from the Proto-Indo-European root *g ∞er- meaning "to rub".

english_translation: to step, to go, to stand
description: Perhaps some variation or gradation of *g ∑em- seen also on *mend ∞- - *meh‚ÇÇd ∞-, *med- - *meh‚ÇÅ-/*meh‚ÇÅd-.

english_translation: to throw, reach, pierce; to hit by throwing
description: On the basis of Celtic nasal-infix present *balnƒ´ti and several Greek derived terms like Œ≤Œ≠ŒªŒµŒºŒΩŒøŒΩ the laryngeal may be reconstructed as *h‚ÇÅ.
Perhaps some variation or gradation of *g ∑eh‚ÇÇ- seen also on *mend ∞- - *meh‚ÇÇd ∞-, *med- - *meh‚ÇÅ-/*meh‚ÇÅd-.

english_translation: to express approval; praise, to elevate
to be warm, to become warm
greyish or brownish coloration, deer, elk, various tree species with bright bark

description: Possibly related to *nem-, to take or give one's due
Schindler, J. (1975). L'apophonie des th√®mes indo-europ√©ens en -r/n. Bulletin de la soci√©t√© de linguistique de Paris, 70.
Alternative reconstruction of the root *h‚ÇÇep-; see there for more

english_translation: to praise, to shine; to sound bright

description: from underlying */h‚ÇÅewg ∑ ∞-/, the schwebeablaut (vowel metathesis) variant of *h‚ÇÅweg ∑ ∞-, with the change *wg ∑ ∞ > *wg ∞ due to the Boukolos rule

english_translation: to help, to assist; to protect

description: The initial laryngeal must be *h‚ÇÅ, not the *h‚ÇÇ suggested by Beekes, or else the Celtic reflexes of the verb would have the wrong vowel; the Celtic verb would surface as **yaigeti with *h‚ÇÇ and **yoigeti with *h‚ÇÉ. Many authors have left the laryngeal unspecified before the Celtic reflexes were established as derived from this root.
Reconstruction:Proto-Indo-European root for atmospheric phenomena and water
Conflated with *h‚ÇÇne·∏±- 'to reach, attain' by Pokorny.
This word may be an intensive derived from *h‚ÇÅep-.
Uncertain if related to *h‚ÇÉreyH- 'to churn, swirl'.

english_translation: to promise, to vow; to praise
to be/become empty, to be extinguished

description: From a univerbation of *dwi-'apart' and *d ∞eh‚ÇÅ-'to put, place'. The initial *d became *h‚ÇÅ due to dissimilation; compare *w√≠d·∏±mÃ•ti > *h‚ÇÅw√≠d·∏±mÃ•ti 'twenty'.

english_translation: to sin, violate, commit a crime

description: This may actually be the same root as *h‚ÇÇeh‚ÇÅ-, considering there is uncertainty concerning the vocalic outcomes of a conflict in coloring rules from two different laryngeals. Moreover, the reconstruction of *h‚ÇÇeh‚ÇÉm√≥s is highly controversial, as is its affiliation with words meaning "hot, heat, burn", and several of its listed descendants are not universally agreed to reflect the same root.

english_translation: to be [[dry]], to dry; to [[burn]], to [[glow]]; [[hearth]]; [[ashes
description: Appears to be suffixed/extended from the root *h‚ÇÇeh‚ÇÅ- as found in cognates; alternatively from *h‚ÇÇed-s- with dissimilation.

english_translation: to cost, have value, be worth
to constrict, tighten, compress; narrow, tight; distressed, anxious
description: Hittite ·∏´amank- 'to tie' suggests that the earlier form should be reconstructed not as *h‚ÇÇen«µ ∞- but as *h‚ÇÇem«µ ∞-, which weakens the argument for a (genetic) relation to Proto-Uralic *a≈ãke 'painfully constricted'. Perhaps related to *h‚ÇÇeng-, *h‚ÇÇenk-, *h‚ÇÇe·∏±-

english_translation: to fit, to fix, to put together, to slot

description: Proto-Indo-European root related to agriculture and ploughing

english_translation: to increase, to enlarge; to become strong
description: From Proto-Indo-European *h‚ÇÇweg-, of which the zero grade *h‚ÇÇug- was reanalysed as having the ablaut vowel before the -w- rather than after it, creating a new variant form of the root. The original root remained in use, however.

Sometimes included is {{noncog|hit|íâ∫íÄÄíÑø|tr=pa-a-i|ts=pƒÅi}}, assuming it contains the prefix {{m|hit|íÅâíÇä-|tr=p√©-e-|ts=pe-}}, but this is made obsolete by the derivation of the Hittite from {{m|ine-pro|*h‚ÇÅep-|t=to seize}}. The identification of the Celto-Germanic isogloss meaning "{{l|en|oath}}" is uncertain, and it may involve borrowing between these two branches. It is more commonly reconstructed as {{m|ine-pro|*h‚ÇÅ√≥ytos}}, from {{m|ine-pro|*h‚ÇÅey-|t=to go}}, without the Greek. Beekes adduces the Greek under the assumption of a connection to the other Greek words belonging to {{m|ine-pro||*h‚ÇÇey-}}, and comparing the semantics of {{cog|ae-yng|ê¨Äê¨âê¨ôê¨Ä|t=punishment}}

Possibly reanalyzed from a compound or suffixed verb *h‚ÇÇ√©yd ∞h‚ÇÅeti, from *h‚ÇÇey- to burn; fire and *-d ∞h‚ÇÅeti to put, set (later resultative suffix); for the root, see also *h‚ÇÇ√©yos (copper?) metal, ore, *h‚ÇÇey- day, *h‚ÇÇ√©yrÃ• day, morning and *ais«≠ fireplace. Alternatively, the root can be identified as *h‚ÇÅay- to be warm, hot, but this root is also contested and poorly evidenced.

english_translation: to obtain, come in possession of, to possess, to own
to wish, to request, to search
to change, exchange; to change places ‚Üí to wander

description: Conflated with *h‚ÇÅne·∏±- 'to receive, take away' by Pokorny.

english_translation: to think, to reason; to arrange
description: Reanalyzed root of *h‚ÇÇer-/√©h‚ÇÅti 'to join; to prepare'

english_translation: to count, count out; to arrange
description: Reanalysed root of *h‚ÇÇr√©yti, from *h‚ÇÇreh‚ÇÅ- 'to think; to count' + *-√©y-present suffix
Perhaps a variant of *(h‚ÇÇ)sew- (to burn), as suggested by Kroonen (2013).

english_translation: to dwell, live, reside; to stay, spend the night
straight, upright, right; right, justice, law

to grab, to grasp, to seize, to take hold, tackle, touch; to swear (an oath)

description: LIV reconstructs *h‚ÇÇ instead of *h‚ÇÉ on account of {{cog|grc|-Œ±ŒºŒ≤ŒøœÇ}} in {{m|grc|Œ∏œÅŒØŒ±ŒºŒ≤ŒøœÇ}} and the like. The o-grade in {{cog|la|ungu≈ç}} must then be analogical from {{cog|la|unguen||fat, cream}}.

english_translation: to call, summon; to assign (to a role or task); to onerate, charge
to work, toil, make; ability, force
to move, to stir; to rise, to spring; to quarrel, fight
to turn; to change allegiance, status, ownership; inheritance (i.e. to change ownership)

description: Possibly reanalyzed root of *h‚ÇÉer- 'to rise' + *-d ∞h‚ÇÅeti 'resultative verbal suffix'

english_translation: to put clothes or shoes on

description: Securely attested only in Indo-Iranian and Greek. Reconstructions with initial *h‚ÇÇ are based on the inclusion of ·ºÄŒºŒ≠œÅŒ≥œâ, though it is unclear how to reconcile the different vocalisms.

english_translation: to roar, to howl, to shout

description: Perhaps an extension of *Hrew-||to tear out, dig out

english_translation: to move, set in motion; to flow, stream (of water); to boil, churn
to enter into, penetrate; to copulate

description: The Proto-Indo-European root for the ash tree.

english_translation: to think, to arrange, to succeed, accomplish
description: Possible reanalyzed root of *h‚ÇÇreh‚ÇÅ- 'to think; to count' and *-d ∞h‚ÇÅeti
Root-final *h‚ÇÇ is reconstructed on the basis of the aspirated dental in Indo-Iranian and perhaps Albanian, but could instead be rebuilt from an original *Hr√©t-h‚ÇÇ ~ HrÃ•t-√©s.

english_translation: to tear out, dig out, open, acquire

Speculative links have been made to *·∏±h‚ÇÇd-|t=to fall.
Reconstruction of a Proto-Indo-European root meaning "to hang".

english_translation: to announce, to proclaim; to put in order
description: Perhaps an old ingressive s-formation of *·∏±em-

english_translation: to grow, to make grow, to nourish

description: Potentially a collective derivation in *-h‚ÇÇ from *·∏±er-||to grow, of which the original root noun may be fossilized in crƒÅs. A possible loan relation with *·∏≥arn-||horn has also been suggested.

english_translation: to be lying down, to settle
description: The meaning "to be lying down" might come from "to have fallen" as the meaning "to fall" occurs in Celtic and Sanskrit.

english_translation: to hold, keep; to close, enclose; that which encloses: fence, hedge, barrier; enclosed space, fenced field, pasture

description: Speculative links have been made to *keh‚ÇÇd- 'hatred, angriness'.
Probably a Lallwort of imitative/expressive origin. Calvert Watkins claimed in particular: "imitative of glottal closure during defecation".
From Proto-Indo-European *·∏±el- "to incline", possibly related to Uralic *kule- "to hear" with metathesis of 'l' and 'w'

english_translation: to seize, to grab; to hold
to rise, to be tall; hill

description: Ultimately derived from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ker-, "to cut". A general word for "to harvest" that had a tendency in some branches to be specialized for the picking of fruit while in others for the reaping of grain.

english_translation: to hit, to strike; to forge

description: According to Lubotsky, all derived terms are actually from *k ∑eyt-/*(s)k ∑eyt-, with loss of labialization in front of *o in Germanic. On the other hand, Kummel argues that the terms at *k ∑eyt- could instead belong to *keyt-.

english_translation: to bend, to curve; to smooth
description: The presence of short *a in all descendants is difficult to explain, and the validity of a root structure *CHeC- is not universally accepted. An alternative, though equally tentative, solution is that some or all of the cognate set are derived from a common substratum continuum. The Greek terms may point to a non-Indo-European substratum.
Possibly from *(s)kh‚ÇÇey- (perhaps whence *hajanƒÖ to pound) with an unknown suffix *-d-, possibly reanalyzed from *sek-/*sekh‚ÇÇ- to cut, sever and *-√©yti.

english_translation: a hook, crook, peg; to close something

description: Formally unable to be related to *gelH-; however, the superficial phonetic and semantic resemblance of the two roots, as well as the existence of words meaning "bald" (a non-basic vocabulary term) in various descendants of both roots via the same suffixing pattern of *-w√≥-s, is striking.

english_translation: to move, be agitated; spring, surge, wave
to pile, stack, place on top, cover
blood outside the body as of a wound

description: Possibly an extended form of *krew(H)- as found in *hrewwanƒÖ and *krun-, to strike, hit. Œ∫œÅŒøœçœâ may reflect either root.
Reanalysed root of *k√©s-rÃ• ~ *ks-√©n-s, from *kes- 'to scrape, comb' with *-rÃ• n-stem suffix.
Reanalysed root of *k√©s-u-s ~ *ks-√©w-s, from *kes- 'to scrape, comb'
Reanalysed root of *ksn√©wti, from *kes- 'to scrape, comb' + *-n√©wti present suffix.

english_translation: to move swiftly, make a swift movement; to swing, shake, to be swinging; to whip, cast, throw
to smoke, to steam; to boil; aroma, strong odor
description: Most likely innovated root, which appeared in Late Proto-Indo-European. Beekes does not suggest Indo-European origin for the Greek data. Rix (in LIV) reconstructs two or three distinct roots: *keuÃØp-, *kuÃØeh‚ÇÅp-, and possibly *kuÃØep-. The Balto-Slavic data is inconclusive - Derksen distinguishes at least two different roots *kwep- (to smell, aroma) and *k ∑h‚ÇÇwep- (to steam, to burn). The root also resembles the wanderwort ŒöœçœÄœÅŒøœÇ (Cyprus), cuprum (copper), which is of Middle Eastern origin.

english_translation: to bubble, to foam; to ferment, become sour

description: Theorized by some linguists, particularly proponents of the Indo-Uralic hypothesis, to be related to the Uralic interrogative root *ku-.

english_translation: to turn, end-over-end; to revolve around, sojourn, dwell
description: The root must be reconstructed with -h‚ÇÅ- in order to explain some forms in Greek and Celtic, including Proto-Greek *k ∑√©lh‚ÇÅ-d ∞e-ti > œÑŒµŒªŒ≠Œ∏œâ and Proto-Celtic *k ∑alnati > Welsh pallu, Old Irish imm¬∑cella. However, this reconstruction contradicts some forms in other languages, e.g. Proto-Italic *k ∑lÃ•-t√≥-s > Latin cultus (not **clƒÅtus < **k ∑lÃ•h‚ÇÅ-t√≥s), which can be explained by various secondary processes.

english_translation: to do, to make, to build
description: The original meaning is often reconstructed as "to carve, to shape by cutting", based on the Anatolian forms.
Some sources reconstruct this root with a laryngeal *k ∑eh‚ÇÅy-.
Per LIV, it is assumed that the root is a t-extension of *k ∑ey-||to estimate

english_translation: to hang down loosely, lip, to lick
description: The reconstruction is uncertain, and contains the rare PIE phoneme *b. A secondary form *lh‚ÇÇP- also exists, with a variety of labials standing in for P. Moreover, the Iranian initial l- is irregular. The root therefore probably originates from a substrate language or is onomatopoeic (imitative of e.g. licking, smacking lips).

english_translation: to gather, collect, with derivatives meaning to speak by carefully selecting one's words
to lie, to be in resting position
to desire, covet, want (someone or something); to admire, praise; to love; to be disturbed

description: Several descendants show abstracting semantic shifts from "to bend down" (or "crouch over") to negative qualities or states of being, but these seem to be independent. Compare the semantics of the English word "stoop".

english_translation: to let, allow; to let go, release
description: Rix suggests that this root derives from the root above. Alternatively related to *leyg- 'to jump around, play'.

english_translation: to jump around, run around; to play, frolic; to shake, jitter; to dance

description: The reconstruction is uncertain due to the fact that the supposed reflexes are present in only three branches.

english_translation: to stick, fat or sticky substance
description: Often supposed to be an extension of *ley-, *(s)ley- 'to slip, slide, glide; slimy'

english_translation: to measure, to give advice, healing
to be wet, to become wet
description: Pokorny, Fortson, and LIV reconstruct this root as an example of an *a-ablauting stem (*mÃ•d- ~ *mad- ~ *mƒÅd-). On the other hand, the regular outcome of *#RÃ•HC- in the descendants can account for many of the reflexes. A lot is uncertain about this root.

The LIV notes that the only satem language evidence for the palatal *·∏± comes from Gothic ê¨®ê¨Äê¨Ø 'great' and its derivatives. The LIV attributes this word to a dialectal variant of Gothic ê¨®ê¨Äê¨∞ from *m√©«µh‚ÇÇs. This would also help explain the short root vowel found throughout the Avestan forms. If Avestan does not belong here, then *meh‚ÇÇk- could very well be the correct form.

english_translation: vivacious, wisdom, to pay attention to

description: An alternative explanation regards the sense 'man, male' as original, as in Hittite. The Latin word pƒìnis presents problems due to the attested chronology of the word's semantics, where 'tail' is older than 'penis', which also aligns with the expected semantic development of such a word (compare e.g. Armenian ’±’•’ø 'tail' > 'penis'); the reverse development is less likely.

description: This root is traditionally considered a lengthened *≈ç-grade of *plew-. The LIV prefers *pleh‚ÇÉ- with either a *-yeti or *-weti present. Derksen suggests either a *-weti present or a conflation of *plew- and *pleh‚ÇÉ-.

A hotly disputed root. Derksen prefers to reconstruct *perH-, to which he also assigns Slavic *pero. Matasovic reconstructs *perHt-. Kroonen reconstructs *pterH- under the assumption of a connection with Ancient Greek œÄœÑŒ≠œÅŒπœÇ, a connection Derksen and Matasovic do not find phonologically likely; Beekes considers the term a later Greek formation. The only point of agreement between them is that the majority of descendants generally assigned to this root, with the exception of œÄœÑŒ≠œÅŒπœÇ, are definitively cognate.

the connection between each form is semantically fine, however their isolation makes this reconstruction suspect

english_translation: to fall into thinking, remember, care for

description: Possibly related to *snus√≥s 'daughter-in-law', suggesting an underlying *snew- root.

Karl Hoffman proposed in 1965 that the original meaning of the root was "to stick, remain", with semantic shift to "snow" (i.e. snow is that which sticks). That sense is still being assigned in LIV. However, that interpretation is highly unlikely, given that all the other daughters except Sanskrit (and also within Indo-Iranian and even Indo-Aryan family itself; cf. Prakrit reflex si·πáƒìha "snow, hoarfrost") point to "to snow" as the original meaning of the root. According to Cheung (2007), Hoffman's explanation that this meaning could have coexisted with the meaning "to snow" is untenable. Cheung (2007) argues that the Sanskrit meaning "to stick, remain; sticky fluid" is secondary (possibly of slang origin) "perhaps from whitish bodily fluids which are compared to snow, notably snot and spit".

english_translation: to be ill, to take care of

description: Attempts have been made to connect this set with *tƒìkanƒÖ, *takanƒÖ||to touch; to grasp, take and t√§k-||to touch, feel (with the hand); to fetch, ce≈õ√§·πÉ|pos=3sg.pres.}, which eo ipso point to *deh‚ÇÅg- (or *deg-/*dƒìg-, which would appear to violate the constraint that prohibits PIE roots of the shape *DeD-); the initial stop in Germanic and the vowel in Tocharian preclude any regular derivation from *teh‚ÇÇg- or *tag-. Hamp has suggested a root *teg- as the source of all of these terms, with zero-grade *t‚Çîg-, which he assumes in pre-Germanic assimilated to *dg-, as the source of forms with /a/ (< *[…ô]). However, this leaves Greek /a/ (zero vowel expected) and the long vowel in êçÑêå¥êå∫êå∞êåΩ unexplained. Mottausch's solution is to assume the reduplicated form *te-th‚ÇÇg- gave rise to pre-Germanic *te-dg-, with regular deletion of an interconsonantal laryngeal in an unstressed syllable plus voicing assimilation, which was back-formed to *de-dg- to restore normal reduplication; the Tocharian may tentatively be grouped under the same formation. Per Kortlandt, the Germanic long *ƒì may thus have developed from dissimilation of this *dedg- to glottalic *deh‚ÇÅg-.

This root is similar to *te·∏±-, and their descendants have partial semantic overlap. Only ’©’•÷Ñ’•’¥ conclusively points to the plain-velar *k, so it is often assumed that the other (Centum) descendants are from *te·∏±-. Though it can be neither confirmed nor disproven, it is also possible that the two are different but related forms of one original root.

The reconstruction of the root-final stop faces some contention with most older sources preferring the labiovelar *k ∑, while other sources question or outright reject the labiovelar in favor of the plain velar *k. The evidence in favor of the labiovelar consists primarily of the Hittite form, while the evidence in favor of the plain velar includes the Tocharian form and the general absence of *-b- in the descendants of *tek( ∑)eti in Celtic languages.

Possibly related to Proto-Uralic *wete, the source of Finnish vesi and Hungarian v√≠z. The nature of the relationship is unclear and controversial; the word may have been borrowed from Proto-Indo-European into Proto-Uralic, or the reverse. A minority of linguists suggests a common origin from an even earlier proto-language, Indo-Uralic, but this is not generally accepted.
